newsitem.title: JAPAN: Adobe CEO says expects PDF to be industry standard.
newsitem.headline: Adobe CEO says expects PDF to be industry standard.

text.p: U.S. graphics-editing software company Adobe Systems Inc said on Wednesday that it expects use of the portable document format (PDF) on the Internet, created mostly with Adobe's Acrobat software, to increase dramatically this year.

John Warnock, the chairman and CEO of Adobe Systems, the third-largest PC software company in the United States, told a Windows World seminar near Tokyo that the use of PDF for electronic content delivery will grow from 10 percent in 1995 to 33 percent in 1997.
"Our goal is...that any corporate document should be able to get into PDF," Warnock said, adding that PDF was becoming an industry standard.
PDF allows production, processing and printing of documents independent of the operating environment, whether it is Windows or Macintosh.
Warnock said copies of the Acrobat Reader are downloaded more than 40,000 times a day.
Electronic publishing and distribution of digital information through a standardised format will sharply cut costs for companies, Warnock said.
Adobe released the Japanese version of Adobe Acrobat 3.0J on May 9.
